BestPartComments: Practicing giving lessons and live coding was great. I got good feedback from fellow attendees, and learned a lot from watching them. I would have liked to spend more time on this. (It's hard to teach much of anything in 90 seconds).    I was glad to learn more of the concrete details about how carpentry workshops are set up and delivered.
ImprovingComments: I felt that much of the material covered lacked practical value, particularly on the first day.     Some of the exercises we were given felt underspecified, and we weren't really given an opportunity to ask clarifying questions before being broken into groups to work on them. Two specific examples come to mind:  1. An instructor went into a long discussion of how to give an introduction. He listed many areas that should be covered. Here are the bullet points he discussed, copy-pasted from the Etherpad:      Introduce Yourself Effectively          What characteristics do you want to convey about yourself?           What will you need to say to convey those characteristics?           Why are you teaching a Software or Data Carpentry workshop?           What should you be careful not to say?    Mechanics         Describe the prerequisites  Highlight main aspects of the schedule.  Communicate the workshop structure  Explain your expectations          Code of Conduct          ways to ask for help          ways to give instructors feedback  Share some advice for success    He told us he was going to break us into groups to practice giving an introduction. This seemed extremely intimidating given the number of points covered. Also, we hadn't covered the Code of Conduct in training at that point, so I didn't even know what it was. He said we should describe the "sticky note system", but I didn't know what that was. We hadn't talked about prerequisites. It felt like we were being suddenly thrown into the deep end.    2. We were given this worksheet (https://carpentries.github.io/instructor-training/files/handouts/Carpentries_teaching_practices.pdf), and these instructions:    Look at the sheet and then---as a group---in this Etherpad provide a list of what teaching practices you would use in each part of a workshop.  Note that part of the challenge here is remembering all of (any of?) the teaching practices that we have covered (feel free to rename them as you remember them).    Here is a list that might be useful: sticky notes (as status flags), minute cards, one up/one down, collaborative note taking (Etherpad), instructor notes, live coding, formative assessments, Code of Conduct, going slowly, concept maps, pre- and post-workshop surveys, accessibility planning, error framing, modeling life-long learning, lesson study, and feedback.      With all due respect, I think this exercise was silly. I guess the boxes in the worksheet were supposed to represent stages of the workshop? Except for the ones inside the "Teaching" box - what are those?     I guess "feedback" is a teaching practice that should go in... the "feedback" box? "minute cards" is one of the items on the list, but I don't think that was even covered in the workshop.     It felt like an exercise in symbol manipulation moreso than actually testing our ability to deliver a workshop.     In general, I would have loved for the whole thing to be more "concrete".     Also, as someone who had never attended a Carpentry workshop before, I felt like there were still a lot of big holes in my understanding of what a Carpentry lesson actually looks like in practice. I would have *loved* to spend an hour watching one of the trainers actually delivering a lesson (maybe with breaks for commentary or questions). I wish we had been able to practice delivering more than 90 seconds worth of content.

BestPartComments: This is the second time I have taken this training. Having completed the training once for Data Carpentry, I decided that I'd prefer to get some actual hands-on teaching experience before beginning to contribute to the Software Carpentry community.     Initially I was reluctant to have to commit two more days to this. However, I thought the fundamental concepts of the course were excellent and was actually glad to have the opportunity to revisit them.
ImprovingComments: If people have laptops in front of them, then they will use them. Over last two days I felt that the length of time for which a trainer talked (without stopping for an exercise) was proportional to the number of people who started checking email on their laptops. I think the rate of this drop-off was particularly severe because the instructors were all online and could not hold people to account. A lot of people have commented on a lack of engagement over the last two days, and have blamed the fact that instructors were remote. However, I don't think this was the problem. The last time I took this course it was also taught remotely and nobody had the same issue. The teaching on both courses was really excellent; the only difference was that previously the interactive exercises were much more staged and more frequent.     One other thing that may improve training would be to mix trainees from sponsoring institutions with those who have made an open application to become a Software/Data Carpentry trainer. It became obvious that several course attendees at this sponsoring institution knew nothing about the Carpentry initiative before starting this course, had not read any of the suggested introductory material, and were ambivalent about attending. Including people from outside institutions who are genuinely pleased to have the opportunity to qualify as an instructor may help motivate those who are perhaps taking this opportunity for granted. It may also help to increase overall engagement with the course.     Finally, I have wondered why instructor training doesn't make use of resources like Project Implicit (https://implicit.harvard.edu/implicit/)? I fully support the emphasis this course places on avoiding potential stereotypes that prejudice minorities within computer science. However, I think there may also be something to be gained from making attendees think about the fact that we all have biases, and it is the ones we are unaware of that may turn out to be the problem.

BestPartComments: The early emphasis that the goal of a workshop is to provide the student with a mental model (instead of a vocabulary of functions, or a precise understanding of a few small code details).
ImprovingComments: I think the workshop loses the plot when you get to Working Memory and Cognitive Load Theory because both of these were misunderstood, or poorly explained.     The limit on working memory means that you need to take care to structure your lessons if the mental model that you are teaching involves more than seven facts and relationships (and they all do). Since you can only teach a small part of the model at a time, you need to sequence your lesson so that the parts build on each other in a useful way. This is a strong motivation for concept maps, and I think you would make this more clear if you move the working memory discussion immediately before concept maps instead of immediately after.    The improtant message about Sweller's Cognitive Load Theory is not that there are three types of load (and that the classification is unfalsifiable). The important message is that students have a limited amount of cognitive load to expend; and as things become automated, they require less load, which is why worked/scaffolded examples do so well. A secondary message is that you need to motivate students to expend load in ways useful to learning.    This leads naturally into a discussion of Mayer's Multimedia Learning Theory, which asserts that available load is distributed across several information channels (at least verbal and visual). If you use multiple modes to make a point (e.g. simultaneously combining spoken explanation with a visual diagram), learning becomes easier. If you try to simultaneously present multiple threads of information in the same mode (e.g. combining spoken explanation with text on a slide) interference occurs and learning is retarded.    This would be the basis for a mature discussion about slides. When are they useful and what makes a good slide? When are they not and what makes a bad slide? Coming out of the workshop, it is easy to assume that teachers should never use slides, but that would be a mistake.     As an example, during parts of this workshop, one of the instructors presented without slides. As a result, I had to mentally keep track of what the instructor had previously said (so I could relate new information to it), and where she was going (so I could clearly see the relationships). I also had to ensure that my attention did not waver during the whole time she was speaking or I would literally lose the plot. This required more load than I could expend, and I did neither of them successfully. I think my understanding of the Carpentries is more vague than it should be because of this.
